awd_titl_txt: Sustainable Pathways from Community College to Bachelor's Degree for Urban Youth in STEM, Northern New Jersey
awd_abstract_narration:
Many academically talented students with demonstrated financial need must work while attending college.  This severely limits their participation in activities designed to foster progress in their academic area of interest, which in turn affects academic success and social integration into college that fosters degree attainment. This project, "Sustainable Pathways from Community College to Bachelor's Degree for Urban Youth in STEM, Northern New Jersey," addresses this situation by creating an innovative approach that provides an ecosystem of financial support and opportunities for students from underserved urban populations to transfer from community college to a four-year institution. The project will provide a total of 295 year-long scholarships to at least 135 talented students who: are pursuing degrees in STEM, have demonstrated financial need, and come from underserved urban areas in New Jersey. The project builds on the Garden State Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) project and the Northern New Jersey Bridges to the Baccalaureate project. Scholars who receive scholarship support in this S-STEM project will be invited to participate in the highly successful activities established by these affiliated projects. Scholarships range from $8,000 for students at Rutgers University, Newark to $4,000 for students at the partnering community colleges (Essex County College, Hudson County Community College, and Passaic County Community College).  

The project's scholars will participate in a new pathway model that is designed to encourage their success, persistence, and transfer from community colleges to 4-year programs; and potentially continuing to graduate school and ultimately to pursuing careers in STEM. Recipients will be randomly selected to receive scholarships and participate in a research study focused on factors influencing their success. These factors include usage of time; self-efficacy, confidence, and aspirations; networking; academic performance; graduation, transfer, and career interest.

por.por_cntn:
This S-STEM project leveraged the Garden State LSAMP project to create a pathway of support for academically talented but financially underprivileged, primarily underrepresented minority students majoring in non-medical STEM from community college through bachelor’s degree. Pell-eligible students with high GPAs were recruited in three community colleges in northern New Jersey in Passaic, Hudson and Essex Counties and were awarded scholarships to cover their tuition and other college expenses. They also joined the Garden State LSAMP or Northern NJ Bridges to the Baccalaureate (NNJB2B) program depending upon the college where they became part of a learning community, received academic support, were given research opportunities and received peer mentoring from S-STEM transfer students from Rutgers University-Newark (RUN) in a program of organized cross-campus peer mentoring. If the community college S-STEM scholars graduated and transferred to RUN as non-medical STEM majors, they received additional S-STEM scholarships to offset the cost of tuition and other expenses for 2 or 3 years to graduation. They also were automatically enrolled in the Garen State LSAMP chapter there and received academic, emotional and additional financial support through graduation.

The program was beset by obstacles from new competing scholarship programs both at the community colleges and RUN that targeted the same students but which did not involve them in the Garden State LSAMP or NNJB2B as well as the Covid pandemic which had its epicenter in the project area. Despite these obstacles, the project was supremely successful. 100% of the community college S-STEM scholars transferred to 4-year programs though not all attended RUN. Most of those who attended RUN received support and flourished. 100% of the Rutgers students were part of the Garden State LSAMP and 90% of these attended the BRAVEN professional development course as part of the S-STEM program. Normally, transfer students earn an average GPA of 3.0 at RUN but S-STEM scholars averaged >3.5 GPA, 3.63 in the final year of the project despite STEM being more challenging than many majors. Research determined that the financial assistance allowed S-STEM scholars to spend more time with academics, research and academic support instead of holding down full-time employment. This shift in commitment allowed the S-STEM scholars to improve their performance and complete their degrees on time (within 5 years). Preliminary data indicate that S-STEM/Garden State LSAMP support encouraged more graduates to attend graduate school and other post-graduate opportunities. The combination of support and programming between LSAMP and S-STEM programs was found to be synergistic, resulting in stronger academic performances, better utilization of available resources and opportunities, faster graduation rates and better success of graduates in non-medical STEM thereby improving the US STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2024
Modified by: Alexander E Gates
